metadata.name: F-1RacingTez #115
metadata.description: F-1RacingTez = Formula 1 Racing Test

metadata.name: Celestial Objects #49
metadata.description:
Celestial Objects is a generative collection imagining planets and stars in the space, with light and shadows being key themes. 

The artwork is primarily rendered using hundreds of thousands of points (more than a million in some cases) to create different aspects of the output including the sky textures, shooting stars and shadows on the planets. 

Celestial Objects is coded in p5.js, and please note that it takes 5-15 seconds for each output to render.

Controls (in live view): 
Press [2] to render 2000x2000px image
Press [4] to render 4000x4000px image
Press [s] to save the current view (default window size or 2000px or 4000px image)

metadata.name: Memo #205
metadata.description:
Memo is a abstract expression of memories written on small pieces of paper, pictures of important moments or a reminder of all the things You have forgotten.

Memo is created with P5JS. Large number of rectangles are packed in loops to the canvas with a random rectangle packing algorithm with simple collision detection. 
The looped area varies from 1 vertical or horizontal rectangle to 8x8 grid. Packed area is created with simple random walking grid loop.
60+ color palettes are handpicked and they can appear reversed. 
One random palette is picked for each piece and p5js.noise() drives the colors, size and angle on the rects with lots of attributes.

Click 'n' to add white noise.
Click 's' to save image as jpeg.

Click '1' to 1x pixelDensity(3600 x 6400 or 6400 x 3600 px - default).
Click '2' to 2x pixelDensity(7200 x 12800 or 12800 x 7200 px).

VGA 2022 / CC BY-NC 4.0

metadata.name: Mugen #83
metadata.description:
Mugen is 夢幻(fantasy) and 無限(infinite).

Features:
- Style: 夢幻(fantasy)/無限(infinite)
- Density: Low/High
- Palette

Live view options:
- Press "s" key after the image is fully drawn: Saves 4200 x 3300 PNG

It may take some time for the drawing to complete, as it is drawn by lots of dots.
Made with p5js.

July 2022
ykxotkx

metadata.name: SCRIBBLERS #28
metadata.description:
Generative animated drawing inspired by mindless doodling and low-res CAD graphics. Custom physics engine made with vanilla javascript. Colors quantized with GLSL. By @galoandstuff.

Use mouse/touch to drag scribbles around and untangle them.
Press ’s’ key to save PNG (live mode only).
Screen size responsive.

metadata.name: Mooncakes: Happy Mid Autumn Festival 2022 #1402
metadata.description:
To celebrate the Moon Festival with Mooncakes, we have created a quest to introduce everyone to fxhash. As part of that quest on mooncakes.fun, users are encouraged to mint this generative token.

This is a layered image composition using the Mooncakes site images on a 1920x1080 canvas. The image elements are randomly assigned position, scale, tint, and blur according to a ruleset which generates a Mid Autumn Festival scene made up of: Moon, Clouds, Stars, Lanterns, and Lotuses.

Special filters, shapes and colors are included as rare features, as well as a couple of surprises.

metadata.name: Apparenza #48
metadata.description:
Apparenza is just the surface of an inner world, of an inner emotional status.
Apparenza sometimes does not represent reality, sometimes it resembles it.

License: CC BY-NC-ND 4.0

@AlfredoBoaron

metadata.name: Bloom in the rain #37
metadata.description:
In the oriental ink and wash paintings, the plain nature and the poetic charm are admired. The seemingly lonely scenery can often reflect the noble sentiment of the literati. In this work, I create a poetic, raining scenery by p5.js. I also reproduce the ink rhythm and texture strokes pattern left by the brush on the rice paper. This is my preliminary exploration of generative art with the form and style of oriental aesthetics.

Created purely with p5.js.
For best result, open in live view 
and press [s] to save a png

Features:
1)	pallete: whiteBackground | darkBackground | color ink
2)	rock position: left | center | right 
3)	number of tree: one | two | three
4)	rain: none | drizzle | shower | heavy | extremely heavy
5)	background type: mountain | ocean 
6)	composition: horizontal_long | horizontal | square
7)	invert color: true | false
8)	moon type: full | slender

This is an original work created by Pingyeh Li, Sep 2022.
License: CC BY-NC-SA 4.0 https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc-sa/4.0/ - @Pingyeh Li

metadata.name: Fractal in the words #61
metadata.description:
Tribute to Herbert W. Franke.

Fractal based on mathematics is placed in Japanese words.

Color Pallet has 10 variations.
Draw Color has 2 variations.
Background Color has 4 variations.

Controls (in live view):
- Press [f] to switch full screen on and off
- Press [s] to download a PNG file with windowsize
- Press [l] to download a PNG file with large size 4000 pixel (wait a minutes)

Create with p5.js
License: CC BY-NC-SA 4.0

metadata.name: Perpetual Oscillations  #73
metadata.description:
Planes expand and contract over time in different rhythms. 

Display notes:
The work is intended to be viewed running live in the browser, and there is no set aspect ratio. The viewer is invited to explore the space and choose their viewpoint. 

Controls:
Left-clicking and dragging - rotate around the center 
right-clicking and dragging - pan around the space 
Scrolling - zoom in and out 
Press b - b-side 
Press o - go back to the origin 
Press 1 to 3 - change the pixel density
Adjusting pixel density or changing the screen size will bring you back to the origin. 

License: CC BY-NC-ND 4.0

Made with p5.js

metadata.name: C-SCAPE #168
metadata.description:
Cellular Automata are one of the oldest and simplest classes of generative systems. Beginning with the highly abstracted, reductionist models of artificial life research by Stanislav Ulam and John von Neumann in the 1940s, Barricelli in the early 1950s, then re-discovered, formalized, expanded and popularized by other mathematicians like Conway and Wolfram 20-30 years later, it's a long-running field of research, rich with unexpected surprises and new discoveries. C-SCAPE is (a partial) result of over 20 years of my own explorations and a celebration of these simple systems.

Most of my purely generative work has been about creating and harnessing emergent complexity & nonrepetitve, ever-changing behaviors (and their interactions) borne from extremely simple systems, mechanisms, algorithms & languages: Exposing, investigating (and yes, celebrating) generativity in its raw form. By minimizing, though not entirely avoiding, additional human aesthetic decision making (here primarily in the form of curating automata rules & color themes), I'm trying to focus the observer on the raw beauty of the underlying processes and bring it to the fore. My hope is, this too will lead viewers asking themselves the deeper questions about the nature of rules, behavior, order and complexity in their own lives, esp. in the current rising polarizing political & anti-science climate. Furthermore, I'd like to provide a counter point and emphasize the unique qualities of generative art, compared to other, more figurative and abstract art approaches.

C-SCAPE simulates a shared toroidal environment in which multiple cellular automata (CA) are evolving and influencing each other, forming short-lived symbioses and/or wiping each other out, only to be restored again later on. The automata are all operating on a single row of pixels at a time and therefore are only 1-dimensional. Yet, many of them also have a short term memory and can produce more complex structures/behaviors by utilizing their memory of previous cell states. Each individually minted version produces a unique system which evolves over time and never repeats.

The final selection of CA rules used in this piece is the result of many years of experimentation with 100,000s of different configurations and many (manual) review/pruning/cataloging sessions to encourage the minted editions to cover a interesting & balanced subset of the more than duodecillion (10^39) possible individual structures & textures (not including interactions and/or color variations)...

Viewing

The piece in best viewed in medium/high resolution landscape format. The horizontal resolution should be at the very least 800 pixels, preferably double that or higher. There's a max. pixel resolution limit of 4096 pixels in either direction, but CPU performance might suffer at these resolutions. On narrow/mobile portrait ratios the piece will be shown 90 degrees rotated and is scrolling sideways.

Controls

- x : export current frame
- r : randomize environment

License

https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc-nd/4.0/

Disclaimer

Minting this project will not guarantee inclusion in access lists for future projects.

Credits

Made in 2022 with <3 and thi.ng

metadata.name: Proxima #18
metadata.description:
The preparations for the first mission began in 2142. It had become clear that mining petroleum on Earth would soon become financially unfeasible, so looking to other planets was the only logical choice. It took seventeen more years to perfect the technology so that the first colonists could reach Proxima b within the lifetime of one generation.

After 45 years of travelling at almost one-tenth of the speed of light, they reached their new home. It was rich in petrochemicals but scarce in the nutrients necessary for long term human survival. After merely six generations, humanity was forced to travel once again in search of a new world. The four missions that parted from the Proxima system to colonise other possibly habitable planets in the galaxy sparked a new age of human civilisation that would never see itself united and thriving again.

Eventually, all the colonies became independent societies as their differing interests drove them apart. Each small civilisation chose its path, wandering the void of space alone. Over time, millions of kilometres apart, each colony developed its own culture and traditions. While their habits and customs changed, some things remained the same across all the societies, like how it became a certain tradition to convert the outer world years and days to Earth time and celebrate holidays according to the calendar of the old world.

The new nomads learned from the first pilgrims. They used the technology once optimised for oil extraction to traverse other worlds, searching for sustenance. Peculiar wandering nonspaces emerged from the involuntary degrowth of human civilisation.

-----

Click on the image to open the menu. You may choose the quality from preview to the resolution of a print of approximately 30cm in height. In live mode, click on PNG to save the rendered image.
Depending on the device and CPU usage, it takes from a few seconds (on fast computers) to a minute (sometimes more) on mid-tier phones to render the image.

Requirements: 1GB of RAM. The system needs up to 200 MB of free RAM for rendering square preview images and up to 400 MB of free RAM for rendering square images at the highest resolution. We tested on Chrome, Safari, Firefox, Edge / Windows, Mac OS, Android, and iPhone, but please make sure it works on your device before minting.

Original piece by mrkswcz and Ismahelio. Made with Three.js. 

San Sebastian - Madrid. May 2022.

attributes.name: world
attributes.value: Gliese 667 Cc. A colourless land under the burgundy light of a red dwarf in a triple-star system.

attributes.name: culture
attributes.value: Hovering. This society perfected the technique of creating structures that allow them to linger above the ground.

attributes.name: community size
attributes.value: A medium-size colony, most similar to today's concept of a city.

attributes.name: festive colors
attributes.value: Classic ruby reminder of the degrowth of the predecessors.

metadata.name: Cuts #31
metadata.description:
Cuts is an abstract representation of the exact moments in our lives when something is cut. It could be moving to a different country, being fired, quitting a bad habit, when a relationship ends or when you receive a very bad (or good!) news.
By themselves, cuts are not positive or negative events; it really depends on who you were before and who you wish to be after. But one thing is sure: every cut creates a new space that wasn’t there. This space could be small or huge, ordered or chaotic, regardless, you have to deal with it. Sometimes cuts try to resist and heal themselves extruding the core of the fibres we are made of, but they will fail. A cut is irreversible and it’s up to us to fill the gap with meaning.

Main features include:
- Curated palettes (21)
- Drawing modes (3)
- Extrusions (yes/no)
- Orientation (3)
- Overlapping (yes/no)
- Covered area (2)
- Cut position (2)

In live mode:
- Press [s] to save a 2400x2400 px image
- Press [t] to toggle shading (sometimes flat colours rock!)
- Press [c] to see copyright notice
- Press [f] to log features in console

By Todemashi 2022
NFT License 2.0

### NOTES
Made with p5js and GLSL shaders.
Shaders are based on tutorials and code by Patricio Gonzalez Vivo - The Book of Shaders - https://thebookofshaders.com/

metadata.name: Zhu(竹) #43
metadata.description:
Zhu(竹):

"Zhu" is a series of 100 oriental abstract pieces featuring the imagery of bamboo, a symbol of integrity and strength in traditional Chinese culture.

Zhu's generative system is an exploration of this cultural symbol by modern art language. Elements of the paintings are merely circles, enclosed flow field shapes, and the blank space behind these visual objects. Blank-leaving is intentionally applied at various degrees throughout the series. The vast empty space beyond the plants is open to and embraces every kind of interpretation.

Zhu's outputs span hours of the day from dawn to dusk to night. Its color schemes explored four styles from traditional to modern. The simple yet complex senses and feelings reflected are surprisingly versatile.
